column1: Calexico () is a city in southern Imperial County
column2: California. Situated on the Mexico–United States border
column3: it is linked economically with the much larger city of Mexicali
column4: the capital of the Mexican state of Baja California. It is about 122 miles (196 km) east of San Diego and 62 miles (100 km) west of Yuma
column6: along with six other incorporated Imperial County cities
column7: forms part of the larger populated area known as the Imperial Valley.

column1: First explored by Europeans in the 18th century
column2: Calexico began as a small tent community which was ultimately incorporated in 1908.

column1: == Etymology ==

The name of the city is a portmanteau of California and Mexico. The originally proposed names were Santo Tomas or Thomasville. Mexicali is a similarly named city directly across the international border from Calexico
column2: its name being a portmanteau of the words "Mexico" and "California".

column1: == History ==
The expedition of Spanish explorer Juan Bautista de Anza traveled through the area some time between 1775 and 1776
column2: during Spanish rule. The trail through Calexico was designated as a historical route by the State of California.

column1: === Founding ===
Calexico began as a tent city of the Imperial Land Company; it was founded in 1899
column2: and incorporated in 1908. The Imperial Land Company converted desert land into a fertile setting for year-round agriculture. The first post office in Calexico opened in 1902.

column1: === 2010 earthquake ===
On April 4
column3: the El Mayor earthquake caused moderate to heavy damage throughout Calexico and across the border in Mexicali. Measuring 7.2 Mw
column4: the quake was centered about 40 miles (64 km) south of the U.S.–Mexico border near Mexicali. A state of emergency was declared and officials cordoned off First and Second streets between Paulin and Heber Avenues. Glass and debris littered the streets of downtown Calexico and two buildings partially collapsed. The Calexico water treatment plant sustained severe damage.

column1: === Climate ===
Calexico has a subtropical hot-desert climate (BWh)
column2: according to the Köppen climate classification system. In December 1932
column3: the city experienced a rare snowfall. Rainfall usually occurs in the winter months of December
column4: January and February. Although summer is extremely dry in Calexico
column6: during the months of July and August there were several heavy thunderstorms that let down large amounts of rain and hail.  Summer rainfall in the city is infrequent. During winter time
column7: Calexico is sometimes affected by winter rain showers.

column1: The summer temperatures in Calexico are very hot
column2: with most of those days having temperatures at or above 100 °F (38 °C). However
column3: the hot desert climate seen in Calexico is actually not unusual for similar parallels

column1: The area has a large amount of sunshine year round due to its stable descending air and high pressure.

column1: == Government ==
The City of Calexico operates under a City Council/City Manager form of government. The City Council consists of five Council Members
column2: elected to overlapping four-year term. The Mayor and Mayor Pro-Tem are chosen from among the five council members and rotate on an annual basis.

column1: The Mayor presides at council meetings
column2: where all official policies and laws of the City are enacted. The members of the Calexico City Council set policy and appoint commissions and committees that study the present and future needs of Calexico.

column1: The other two elected officials in the City of Calexico are the City Clerk and City Treasurer. Each of them is elected directly by the voters and serves a four-year term.

column1: Calexico became a center of the national debate on border security as Vice President Mike Pence and Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen toured Calexico in 2018. American President Donald Trump proposed expansion of the border wall between Mexico and the US to prevent illegal entry by foreign nationals through Mexico into the US during his presidential campaign and upon being elected. Trump visited the barrier at the border with Mexico in April 2019 which was described by his office as “a newly completed section of the promised border wall.”  He had proposed closing the border which concerned many in Calexico since the regional economy depends on daily border crossing. Mexicans come daily to work in the agriculture fields and to shop or use other services. Likewise
column2: people travel from Calexico into Mexico to obtain services or visit relatives.
